metadata.title: Recommender system using Bayesian personalized ranking | by Akhilesh Narapareddy | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Recommender system using Bayesian personalized ranking
metadata.description: In this post, I will be discussing about Bayesian personalized ranking(BPR) , one of the famous learning to rank algorithms used in recommender systems. Before going into the details of BPR…

all_paragraphs: In this post, I will be discussing about Bayesian personalized ranking(BPR) , one of the famous learning to rank algorithms used in recommender systems. Before going into the details of BPR algorithm, I will give an overview of how recommender systems work in general and about my project on a music recommendation system. This will help some of you who are reading about recommender systems for the first time and serve as a refresher for the others.

Earlier in the days of Netflix prize, most of the recommender systems were based on explicit data(ratings data) where users explicitly give ratings to express their opinion. A lot has changed since then. With enhancements in data collection techniques and decrease in the trend of giving explicit ratings among customers, implicit feedback data has become more popular in both academia and industries to build robust recommender systems.
Implicit data is nothing but the feedback that we collect from customers in the form of clicks, purchases, number of views e.t.c. Main features of implicit data are

For implicit data, Latent factor models provide an alternative approach to neighborhood models(models based on similarity measures) that helps in uncovering the latent features of users and items. Examples of such models are Matrix factorization, Latent semantic models, Latent dirichlet allocation e.t.c. Of them, matrix factorization has become more popular due to its attractive accuracy and scalability.
Although a simple Singular value decomposition works for this purpose, it suffers from over-fitting which takes us to the next set of models which involve regularization.

Learning recommender systems is one such approach where the matrix factorization can be reformulated as an optimization problem with loss function and constraints. In this approach, we choose the best recommender out of a family of recommenders during the optimization process. The final result of this approach is a latent factor model which helps us in uncovering the latent features of the users and the items using parameter estimation methods.
To elaborate on this, lets look at the structure of learning recommender system
As shown in the figure above, there are 3 components in a learning recommender system:

Model can be a matrix factorization model or a linear regression model. It has some parameters like matrices in a matrix decomposition that we would be optimizing during the process. In our case, the model along with the parameters constitute the recommender system
This is like any other loss function that we have in a machine learning algorithm and will be minimized to arrive at an optimum solution
Θ : Parameters of our recommendation model like user and item matrices in matrix factorization.
g(θ): Loss function that we are trying to minimize
We can choose any optimization algorithm that fits our purpose. For implicit data, one of the best optimization algorithms is Alternating least squares
Performance of these recommender systems often depends on the optimization algorithm that is being used.
You guessed it. Next part is about optimization algorithms and we are getting closer to Bayesian personalized ranking.

Alternating least squares(ALS) is one such algorithm that was proposed in Collaborative filtering for implicit feedback by Yifan Hu, Yehuda Koren and Chris Volinsky. I would strongly recommend to read this article by Victor to understand ALS in detail if you are not aware of this algorithm.However, I will give a brief overview of ALS model in order to maintain logical continuity to Bayesian personalized ranking approach.
ALS is an algorithm that optimizes the user and item latent vectors iteratively by keeping one vector constant during a particular iteration.

In their paper, Yifan Hu and others came up with the concept of attributing confidence to the users choices while performing an action.They formulated a new square loss function that includes both preference and confidence metric which in turn will be optimized using ALS method.
xu and yi are user latent vector and item latent vector respectively.

To gain a better understanding of recommender system using ALS, i implemented these concepts to create a music recommender system using an open source music dataset(lastfm dataset). I took inspiration and some code help from the works of Ben Frederickson and Jesse Steinweg-Woods while building this music recommender system.
You can find the code for this project in my github repository.

I have used AUC metric as an evaluation criterion for this recommender system. It is important to note that this dataset is very sparse and had sparsity of 99.9% when I took a sample of 40000 users and 100000 artists. Inspite of the large sparsity in the dataset, the recommender system gave an AUC value of ~90%.

Although, the algorithm is performing better in terms of finding similar artists, I was not getting satisfactory results in recommending artists to a particular user. This takes me to the final section of this post.

Although, ALS approach by Yifan Hu reduces the impact of missing data using confidence and preference metrics, it does not directly optimize its model parameters for ranking. Instead it optimizes to predict if an item is selected by a user or not. Bayesian Personalized Ranking optimization criterion involves pairs of items(the user-specific order of two items) to come up with more personalized rankings for each user.

First of all, it is obvious that this optimization is on instance level (one item) instead of pair level (two items) as BPR. Apart from this, their optimization is a leastsquare which is known to correspond to the MLE for normally distributed random variables. However, the task of item prediction is actually not a regression (quantitative), but a classification (qualitative) one, so the logistic optimization is more appropriate. —
Steffen Rendle, Christoph Freudenthaler, Zeno Gantner and Lars Schmidt-Thieme in BPR: Bayesian Personalized Ranking from Implicit Feedback

The primary task of personalized ranking is to provide a user with a ranked list of items. In the below section, i have summarized the approach by minimizing the number of mathematical equations to make it easy for the first time reader. You can refer to the original paper for understanding the math in detail.
Let U be the set of all users and I be the set of all items. Below figure shows, how implicit data is treated in case of general item recommenders.

Usual approach is to predict a personalized score xui for an item that reflects the preference of the user for the item. After that, the items will be ranked based on that score. Here as you can see in the figure above, all the existing interactions between user and item are labelled as a positive class(1) and the rest of the interactions are being labelled as negative class(0) .

This implies that if our model fits the training data exactly, it is going to treat all the interactions that are not present in the training data in the same manner as all of them are labelled as 0. This approach will not necessarily consider rank in the future recommendations.

In BPR approach, instead of taking one item, item pairs will be considered as training data. Optimization would be performed based on the rank of these user-item pairs instead of scoring just on the user-item interaction. The dataset that would be considered is formulated as follows
The semantics of (u, i, j) ∈ DS is that user u is assumed to prefer i over j.
Here the triplets generated for training data, are user-specific pair-wise preferences between a pair of items.

In the above figure, user u1 has viewed item i2 but not item i1, so the algorithm assumes that this user prefers item i2 over i1( i2 > i1) and gives a positive sign. No inference can be made about a preference for items that were both been seen by a user and is shown as ? mark. The same is true for two items that a user has not seen yet (e.g. item i1 and i4 for user u1). On contrary, you can observe a negative sign for (i1,j2) as user prefers item2 over item1.
Like in any Bayesian approach, we have a likelihood function , prior probability and posterior probability in this approach.

The Bayesian formulation of finding the correct personalized ranking for all items i ∈ I is to maximize the following posterior probability where Θ represents the parameter vector of an arbitrary model class (e.g. matrix factorization).
Here, >u is the desired but latent preference structure for user u. It is also important to note that p( >u | θ) is a user specific likelihood function.

Assuming that the users would act independently and the ordering of each pair of items (i, j) for a specific user is independent of the ordering of every other pair, we can formulate the individual probability that a user prefers item i to item j as follows:

x^uij (Θ) in the above equation is a real valued function that represents the relation between user u , item i and item j and is generally calculated by using Matrix factorization model. In other words, scores that capture the relation between user u, item i and item j will be calculated using the triplet training data and matrix factorization and is wrapped in a sigmoid function. This sigmoid function gives the individual probability that will be optimized during the process.
p(θ) is the prior probability which is a normal distribution with zero mean and variance-covariance matrix
Following equation is the final BPR-OPT criterion, that has to be optimized
where λΘ are model specific regularization parameters
Now that we have the probability function, one of the common ways to evaluate it is a log likelihood function.

The reason to use logarithmic function is numerical stability. It turns out that for very large datasets , there is a possibility that we get very low probabilities that are difficult for the system to record. By taking a log of the probability, we get a summation instead of a product of the probability of each point and would be efficient to store in computer memory.

To people who do not know about AUC, it is the Area under the ROC curve which is plotted with True positive rate as the y axis and False positive rate as x — axis for various thresholds of the model that is being considered. In other words, for a set of item recommendations, we can plot the ROC curve by calculating the %good item recommendations and %bad recommendations for each threshold.
It is interesting to note that the AUC metric is a rank based metric and can also be considered as percentage of correctly ranked points.
Mathematically speaking, the AUC of a classifier is equal to the probability that the classifier will rank a randomly chosen positive example higher than a randomly chosen negative example.
Implementing AUC definition for our use case gives us the following equation:
S(i;u) > S(j;u) is the x^uij score that we were discussing earlier.

The function 1{foo} is a non-differential Heaviside function. A general practice while optimizing for AUC(rank based metric) is to replace the Heaviside function with a differentiable function like sigmoid function. In our case ,we have chosen the log(sigmoid). This concept is summarized in the following paper.
Optimizing for BPR-OPT criterion will be similar to optimizing for AUC which is a rank based metric as we can see from the above equation.

When the criterion is differentiable as in this case, obvious choice is to use gradient descent on the optimization criterion. But in this case, the order in which the models traverses the training pairs is crucial. Following the general stochastic gradient approach would lead to poor convergence as there are so many consecutive updates on the same user-item pair — i.e. for one user-item pair (u, i) there are many j with (u, i, j) ∈ DS.

To tackle this issue, a bootstrapping method has been followed in this algorithm. Instead of taking the data points in a sequential order i.e all the item (i), item (j) for a particular user, taking points at random leads to a faster convergence. This has been verified empirically by the authors of BPR approach.

The last step of this post is to understand how matrix factorization model calculates x^uij score. Matrix factorization in general tries to model the hidden preferences of a user on an item. It is a real number x^ui per user item pair(u,i).
As we have triplets in our data, the estimator x^uij will be decomposed as follows:

We can use any standard collaborative filtering model instead of matrix factorization to predict the x^ui and x^uj. BPR-OPT criterion is optimal for ranking task as we are classifying the difference of two predictions (x^ui -x^uj).

Implicit package by Ben Frederickson has a module for BPR and is quite easy to implement for any dataset. You might want to take a look at that to implement this approach in python for your recommender system.

That’s all folks. I hope you have a good understanding of Bayesian personalized ranking approach now. I will be implementing this as a next step for my music recommender system and check its performance in terms of ranking in my recommendations.
Stay tuned for more posts on statistics in data science and data visualizations in the coming weeks!
